docs.lead_paragraph: IN the 10 months since Filipe Pereira moved with his wife, Michiko, and their three children to this village along the Hudson River, he has met more neighbors than he did during the previous four years living in another Westchester community. ''That must say something -- that Hastings is a very friendly place, and everyone fits right in here,'' observed Mr. Pereira, a housing contractor who was raised in Brazil and has met some fellow villagers while playing soccer with a local adult team. His wife, who was born and raised in Japan, has similarly settled in.

headline.main: If You're Thinking of Living In/Hastings-on-Hudson; Hilly Riverfront Village With 50's Flavor

docs.lead_paragraph: THEY are a motley team, the four members of John Kerry's war room for economic policy. Remember Roger C. Altman, the high-ranking Treasury official in the early Clinton years, forced out for being too loyal to his boss in the Whitewater investigation? He is one of them. Gene Sperling, a White House insider in all eight Clinton years, is another. Then there are two less-known 30-somethings: Jason Furman, a Harvard-trained economist, hired so recently that he is still working out of his Greenwich Village apartment, and Sarah Bianchi, who was Al Gore's policy adviser in 2000 and is now Mr. Kerry's. Both got their start in the Clinton White House, as young aides barely out of college.

headline.main: A Kerry Team, A Clinton Touch

docs.abstract: Sen John Kerry's top economic advisers for his presidential campaign all come from Clinton administration and have drawn from that experience in fleshing out Kerry's plans; they are Roger C Altman, Gene Sperling, Jason Furman and Sarah Bianchi; are rapidly developing specific proposals and constructing galaxy of advisers who vet proposals and often contribute to them; they say challenges are different than during Clinton administration; photos (M)
docs.snippet: THEY are a motley team, the four members of John Kerry's war room for economic policy.    Remember Roger C. Altman, the high-ranking Treasury official in the early Clinton years, forced out for being too loyal to his boss in the Whitewater...

docs.lead_paragraph: Sumi Gupta, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Prem Gupta of Roslyn, N.Y., was married last evening to Michael Seth Glickman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George Glickman of New Hyde Park, N.Y. Pandit Mahesh Shastri, a Hindu priest, officiated at the Crest Hollow Country Club in Woodbury, N.Y. Cantor Henry Weintraub took part in the ceremony. Mrs. Glickman, 26, is a candidate for an M.B.A. at Fordham University. She graduated from Columbia. Her father is a cardiologist in Brooklyn and also a clinical professor of medicine at the State University's Downstate Medical Center, also in Brooklyn. The bride's mother, Neelam Gupta, manages her husband's medical practice.

docs.lead_paragraph: LONG-TERM care insurance is one of those financial products you know you should have but can't imagine being able to afford. If you don't have it and eventually need it, you'll be kicking yourself. If you buy a policy and don't use it, you may still be kicking yourself. Then there are your parents. If they don't have the insurance, it's your assets -- money you were saving for Junior's college education or your own retirement -- that may eventually be used to provide their care.

headline.main: The New Math of Long-Term Care Insurance

docs.abstract: James Schembari column on new long-term care insurance options that let couples share coverage and make it easier for adult children to cover their parents; notes high costs; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: INSIDE the pamphlet from the Cleaning Authority is a picture of two smiling women armed with buckets and cleanser, beckoning readers to drop their DustBusters. Television commercials for Merry Maids show their employees jogging across the screen carrying vacuum cleaners. Telephone directories list A-1 American Maid Service to X-tra Cleaning. It's a far cry from the hand-printed notice on the community bulletin board at the Stop & Shop advertising the cleaning services of Anna, who is ''honest, reliable and trustworthy with very great references.'' Housecleaning, once the province of freelancers whose advertising budgets were measured in thumbtacks and whose business spread mostly by word of mouth, has gone corporate.

headline.main: The Cleaning Lady Has Gone Corporate

docs.lead_paragraph: Built from the ashes of the Watts riots, the Martin Luther King Jr./Charles R. Drew Medical Center is more than brick and mortar. It is a symbol of a racial movement, a public hospital built for blacks and run by blacks, set in the middle of one of the roughest areas in Los Angeles. But over the last decade, the hospital has stumbled -- fallen so far, in fact, that some doctors, Los Angeles County officials and civil rights lawyers call it a catastrophe of corruption, institutional paralysis and ineptitude.

headline.main: Watts Symbol of Hope Becomes Center of Conflict

docs.abstract: Martin Luther King Jr/Charles R Drew Medical Center in Watts section of Los Angeles was once proud jewel of civil rights movement; county officials and civil rights lawyers now call it catastrophe of corruption, institutional paralysis and ineptitude; county sent in new management team in December, and federal government has threatened to suspend funding if conditions do not improve; national accreditation board has rescinded medical school's authority to train surgeons and radiologists; King/Drew is only public hospital in South Los Angeles; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration approved yesterday the first H.I.V. test that uses saliva rather than blood and delivers results in 20 minutes. Public health officials hope the new test will encourage wider and more frequent testing. About 25 percent of all Americans carrying H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS, do not know that they are infected, according to estimates by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Around the world, according to the World Health Organization, that figure may be as high as 95 percent.

headline.main: Fast Saliva Test for H.I.V. Gains Federal Approval

docs.abstract: Food and Drug Administration approves first HIV test that uses saliva rather than blood and delivers results in 20 minutes; OraSure Technologies, company that developed test, is not yet seeking right to sell it over the counter; OraSure pres Michael Gausling says test is over 99 percent accurate and offers no risk of transmission; Dr Anthony S Fauci, prominent AIDS researcher, praises new test; his photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: ''New Heart Studies Question the Value of Opening Arteries'' (front page, March 21) raises another question. Since scientific evidence says heart disease is a systemic illness, why do doctors continue to perform millions of these targeted procedures, like angioplasty, bypasses and the insertion of stents?

headline.main: A New Prescription for the Heart

docs.abstract: Dr Debra Braverman letter responds to March 21 article; holds that Medicare and private insurers should stop paying so indiscriminately for procedures like angioplasty, bypasses and insertion of stents

docs.lead_paragraph: Thousands of people who live or work in Lower Manhattan and were exposed to the dust plume after the World Trade Center attack would be eligible to undergo health screening under a bill expected to be introduced in Congress on Monday. The legislation would greatly expand an existing health monitoring program that covers New York City firefighters and about 12,000 others who responded to the attacks.

headline.main: Bill Would Help Thousands Exposed to 9/11 Dust Plume

docs.abstract: Thousands of people who live or work in Lower Manhattan and were exposed to dust plume after World Trade Center attack would be eligible for health screening under bill to be introduced in Congress by Reprs Carolyn Maloney and Christopher Shays (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Striking workers at the Oyster Bar restaurant in Grand Central Terminal returned to work yesterday after reaching an agreement that ended their nearly four-month walkout. The restaurant, a landmark of old New York that opened with the terminal in 1913, did not close after nearly 100 waiters, oyster shuckers, dishwashers and other workers went on strike on Dec. 5. But the workers said that their walkout had badly cut business.

headline.main: Four-Month Walkout Ended At Oyster Bar Restaurant
